India generally doesn't allow dual citizenship. Since 2020, Indian embassies and consulates have been requiring former Indian citizens to renounce their Indian citizenship, upon acquiring a citizenship of another country (for example by naturalization in Canada). Unfortunately according to the Indian Citizenship Act, when an Indian citizen renounces their Indian citizenship, from that date onwards both that person, as well as all minor children of that person if any, cease to being Indian citizens. In such a case, if the minor children weren't naturalized with the above parent, they would legally become stateless.

This is a guide on how to best avoid that situation, at least until the authorities correct the situation.

Section Header

  1. Just because one parent acquires foreign citizenship after the birth of the child, doesn't mean that the child immediately becomes stateless. That only happens when that parent renounces their Indian citizenship as per Section 8 of the Indian Citizenship Act 1955.

It also explains why some consulates say despite the acquisition of the foreign citizenship, any children of that person don't lose their Indian citizenship. It's technically true so long as this person doesn't renounce their Indian citizenship.

  1. There's no legal requirement to renounce as Indians automatically lose their Indian citizenship on acquiring foreign citizenship as per Section 9 (Automatic Termination) of the law above. The only requirement is to surrender your Indian passport which doesn't require you to also renounce as per Section 9.

  2. There's again a High Court Case about the ramifications of Automatic Termination (Section 9) vs Renunciation (Section 8), so my interpretation is supported by case law. You can read it here: https://indiankanoon.org/doc/169495769/

  3. The consulates/embassies might force you to sign a renunciation declaration when applying for OCI. I think it would be worth asking, if it can be applied for, without that renunciation certificate, especially since the Indian citizenship was already automatically lost as per Section 9.

  4. For people that are in the precarious situation where one parent acquired foreign citizenship after the birth of the child, they can prevent the loss of the child's Indian citizenship by not renouncing as per Section 8. Instead try to get OCI without renunciation, and if that doesn't work, get e-visa, X-visa until the child is also naturalized to prevent statelessness.

  5. People fail to realize that the opinions of the embassies/consulates are not legally binding. The consulates/embassies that say, yes even if any parent (mother or father) renounces their Indian citizenship won't be liable if in the future the government insists the child has lost their Indian citizenship (as that is legally the case). The executive branch (ministries, consulates/embassies) can't override parliamentary law.
